turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Telephone.
turn.2: When the called party picks up the handset, they actuate a double-circuit switchhook (not shown) which may simultaneously disconnects the alerting device and connects the audio circuitry to the line.
turn.3: What happens if there is no Hook Switch?
turn.4: This, in turn, draws direct current through the line, confirming that the called phone is now active.
turn.5: What happens if the called phone is not active?
turn.6: The exchange circuitry turns off the ring signal, and both telephones are now active and connected through the exchange.
turn.7: What can you do through the exchange?
turn.8: The parties may now converse as long as both phones remain off hook.
turn.9: What happens if one phone is placed back on the hook?
turn.10: When a party hangs up, placing the handset back on the cradle or hook, direct current ceases in that line, signaling the exchange to disconnect the call. Calls to parties beyond the local exchange are carried over trunk lines which establish connections between exchanges.
turn.11: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.12: In modern telephone networks, fiber-optic cable and digital technology are often employed in such connections.
